awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Smart Material Composites and Design of Internal Structural Geometry for Tunably Compliant Soft Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will demonstrate soft robots that can radically modulate their stiffness in a manner comparable to biological systems. This ability will enable robots that can safely collaborate with human co-workers in the service and manufacturing industries. The creation of intrinsically flexible robots using materials such as soft rubbers and foams is a stark contrast to the traditional paradigm of large, heavy, rapidly moving robotics in isolated environments, and has played an important role towards moving robots from the factory floor to the home, clinic, and office. However the intrinsic compliance that makes soft materials safe also makes them unable to exert large forces or to maintain their shape when acted upon by outside forces. In many biological systems, animals are able to change the magnitude and directionality of their soft tissue stiffness through muscle contractions and modification of internal fluid pressures. This project will show researchers how to use controllable compliance in robotic components to obtain the benefits of soft materials -- adaptability, fault tolerance, and safety -- while also providing greater force and manipulation capabilities. The results will find application in a wide range of applications, including home health care, medical interventions, factory automation, and disaster response. The simplicity and safety of experimental exploration with soft robotics also provides an ideal platform for high schools students and undergraduate students to get involved in the emerging field of soft robotics.

The central hypothesis of this research is that the development of tunable compliance - with respect to location, magnitude, and directionality - will provide greater dexterity and control and allow soft robotic designs to exert larger and more precise forces on their environment. This work will research the effects of compositing smart materials with existing soft robotic components to identify the fundamental principles of geometric design of the smart material aggregate. The intention is to imbue soft robots with the ability to dynamically adjust the magnitude, spatial location, and directionality of their compliance. These three aspects of tunable compliance will require new methods of modeling kinematics and dynamics as a function of the control of the smart material stimuli, in conjunction with other traditional actuation schemes such as tendons and pneumatics. Another primary result of the project will be quantitative metrics to objectively describe the capabilities of the resulting tunably compliant robots, in order to formally optimize the geometry of the smart material aggregate.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were the development of tunable compliance -- with respect to location, magnitude, and directionality -- as an added capability to the emerging field of soft robotics. This tunable compliance provides greater dexterity and control and allow soft robotic designs to exert larger and more precise forces on their environment. The added capabilities are contained within three specific aims, namely (1) stiffness variability through the compositing of smart materials, (2) stiffness variability through geometric design and control, and (3) the discovery of quantitative metrics for assessing the degree of stiffness variability for soft robotics. All of the work was accomplished through the compositing of smart materials with traditional soft robotic materials.

Early work was conducted through the compositing lattices of low melting point alloys or polymers inside of rubber enclossures. By selectively controling the location and directionality of the melting of these internal lattice structures, the spatial location and directionality of compliance could be controlled. However, the phase change between solid and liquid made stiffness variability much more difficult with this particular design.

Later work was conducted through the compositing of pneumatic chamber with fibers and shape memory alloys (SMAs). We call this type of actuator a PneuSMA actuator. The SMAs serve as variable stiffness fibers that were attached to the surface of the pneumatic chambers. As such, even with a single pneumatic chamber, complex geometries of bending were accomplished through the geometric patterning of the SMAs on the surface of the chamber and the portions of the SMA elements that were activated.

Both of these efforts exploited the paradigm of using traditional soft robotic actuation techniques - pneumatics and tendons - to perform the high force actuation of the devices. The composited smart materials performed the role of locally modifying the underlying mechanics of the soft robotic structure. This approach to soft robotics holds the promise of enabling better geometric scaling that existing methods of many chamber and many pneumatic tubes.

Throughout the project, outreach activities were conducted to expose high school students to the exciting aspects of soft robotics. Mutliple learning modules were created to demonstrate the composite approach to soft robotics. Additionally, hands on activities were conducted with Washington State University's Native Youth Exploring Higher Education program in which middle and high school students built small soft robotic inchworms by compositing 3D printed soft materials and shape memory alloy coils to create a locomoting soft robot.


Last Modified: 01/05/2023
Modified by: John P Swensen

Images (1 of )
  • A description of how the PneuSMA actuator is a composite of a pneumatic chamber and shape memory alloy (SMA) acting as variable stiffness fiber reinforcement
    Emily Allen
    Copyrighted
    John P Swensen
    PneuSMA Actuator Principles of Operation
  • Unique actuation motions of soft robots accomplished through selective fiber reinforcement and pneumatic actuation.
    Emily Allen
    Copyrighted
    John P Swensen
    Fiber-reinforced soft robot
  • A soft robot created through compositing of low melting point polymers, rubber enclosure, and actuated via tendon
    Emily Allen
    Copyrighted
    John P Swensen
    Lattice-based Composite Soft Robot
  • Further details concerning the fabrication and design of PneuSMA actuators. The shape memory alloy (SMA) elements are secured to the walls of the pneumatic chamber via a helical wrap.
    Emily Allen
    Copyrighted
    John P Swensen
    PneuSMA Actuator Design
  • A description of how the combination of pneumatic activation and shape memory alloy (SMA) activation contributes to the resultant shape of the PneuSMA device. Here, the red sections represent SMA portions that are heat activated.
    Emily Allen
    Copyrighted
    John P Swensen
    PneuSMA Actuator Control
  • Contributions of the PneuSMA actuator to the field of soft robotics, and in particular work where shape memory alloys (SMAs) are used and one of the actuation methods. This work created models that don't require stress or temperature measurement, thus enabling easier inclusion in embedded systems.
    Emily Allen
    Copyrighted
    John P Swensen
    PneuSMA Actuator Summary of Contribution
